title-group.article-title: The limits to wind power and the cost of standby generation

article-meta.aff: Risk Management, Reliability and Maintenance Group, School of Engineering and Mathematical Sciences, City University, London EC1V 0HB, UK

fn.p: This manuscript was submitted as part of the Special Issue on Nuclear Energy, Volume 226, Issue 3, May 2012.

abstract.p: Based on general considerations and a relatively small amount of easily available UK data, it is shown that the electricity grid should be able to absorb wind power’s full output up to a wind penetration of about 17.5 per cent. This is demonstrated not to constitute a hard limit, however, and almost all wind power’s output can be absorbed up to a penetration of about 50 per cent, a much larger fraction than has been acknowledged generally hitherto. Thus, the theoretical limits to wind power are rather wide. However, the analysis does not attempt to account for the practical difficulties imposed on the standby generators needed to match supply to demand in the presence of intermittent wind power. The intermittency of wind means that wind power generators need to provide standby generation if they are to contribute to maintaining the continuity of electric power supply that is prized so highly in all modern civilizations. The Declaration Obligation Model (DOM) has been introduced based on the notion that in return for a guarantee from the grid to purchase all the wind power that wind farms can produce at all times, each wind power operator will make a declaration that he will supply an amount of power sent out equal to the maximum continuous rating of his wind farm. A substantial offset for the cost of the standby generation is provided by the fact that the DOM allows for the recovery of revenue from the standby generators selling the shortfall of electricity when wind power operators are unable to meet their obligations from their wind turbines. The cost of this back-up generation is understood most easily by calculating the ‘standby premium’, the fractional additional cost of wind energy needed to cover the necessary level of back-up capacity. The cost of standby emerges as relatively modest. For today’s costs for wind power and gas generation, the standby premium is about 12 per cent for offshore wind and 16 per cent for onshore, if gas generation provides the standby plant. Wind power will become competitive with general power production when the fuel cost per MWh associated with general generation has risen to match the levelized cost of constructing and operating the wind turbines without standby. This prompts the notion of wind power as a fuel-saving adjunct to general power production rather than as a wholly independent source of energy.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The ability to satisfy the consumer’s fluctuating requirement for electricity at all times is a public good that has come to be appreciated as a prerequisite of modern civilization. Demand is highly inelastic, and the ability to always meet consumer demand is given a concomitantly high value, as reflected in the price structure to which wholesale electricity suppliers must conform. In the UK, for example, all generators except for wind generators who have contracted to provide power but find that they cannot, perhaps as a result of an unplanned shutdown, have a duty to buy in extra power from others to make up the shortfall. Perforce purchased on the spot market, this power will almost invariably have a much higher cost than its contracted selling price. Hence, generating companies in potential default of their obligation to supply firm power at the time agreed will be effectively penalized for their inability to provide it from their own resources.

As noted above, wind power generators in the UK are currently exempted from this requirement to provide firm power. The exemption, which is a form of subsidy, arises from the desire of successive governments to encourage the development of a wind power industry in the UK from scratch. However, subsidies retained into the long term will have a distorting effect on markets, and the question arises as to the amount of back-up generation that wind generators should provide, and how much this adds to the cost of wind power generation. A conceptual model will be introduced and developed to cost the obligation to contribute to meeting the nation’s requirement for electric power on call. This will require backup or standby generation from sources other than wind. ‘Standby generation’ and ‘back-up generation’ will be regarded as synonymous in this article.

It will be assumed that the standby generation will be produced by a power plant of unspecified type: a ‘general’ power plant. Gas power generation is currently the market leader in the UK, offering both flexibility in adjusting to demand and competitive costs, and so gas may provide the necessary standby capacity, at least in the short term, but this article does not make that assumption.
General electric power generation and wind electric power generation will be referred to hereafter as ‘general power production’ and ‘wind generation’, respectively.

The figures used in the analysis derive from current usage of the electricity grid, and are therefore applicable fully to the existing situation. However, it is suggested by the Committee on Climate Change [1] that some future forms of electricity consumption can cope well with intermittency, for example electric vehicle batteries on charge, while more sophisticated metering applied to some existing uses, such as storage heaters, should allow them to work well when supplied by an intermittent energy source. In both these cases, it is the sum total of the electricity used over a prolonged time interval that is important, rather than its value at any particular instant. ‘Flexible demand’, as just described, is projected to rise to 15 per cent of the total by 2030. However, this still leaves 85 per cent of electrical demand needing to be satisfied at call in 2030. This means that the fundamentals of the analysis presented here will be relevant to the large bulk of electricity demand in 20 years’ time.

Wind generation is marked out from the other forms of power production by its intermittent nature as a result of its dependence on weather conditions. While all forms of generation need backup if continuity of supply is to be maintained at a high level, despite the good reliability of wind turbines, the requirement for backup is much greater for wind farms than for gas-fired power stations, for example. Not only is the average power produced only a small fraction of capacity for wind installations but there is a relatively high frequency of widespread becalming when the output from each of the UK’s wind farms will be low or zero at the same time. Hence, while the cost of backup provision adds little to the cost of conventional plant, it is a factor to which attention has to be paid in the case of wind power.

It is useful to characterize the additional cost of standby generation in terms of the ‘standby premium’, the fractional increase in the levelized cost of wind energy needed to account for standby generation. Some previous estimates of the standby premia for wind have been as high as 31 per cent for offshore wind and 46 per cent for onshore (based on figures given in Royal Academy of Engineering [2]). However, the cost of standby generation and hence the standby premium will depend on how often the back-up power is called upon, and in what quantities. These will be influenced in turn by the strategy for utilizing wind power. This article will introduce a strategy denoted the ‘Demand Obligation Model (DOM)’, based on using all the wind power produced as far as is feasible. It will be shown that this costing model cuts the size of the standby premia very significantly.

It is necessary to establish the range of applicability of the DOM as the penetration of wind power rises, and this entails an exploration of the feasible region for the grid accepting all the power that can be supplied by wind. It will be shown how theoretically almost all the wind power produced can be absorbed up to a wind penetration of about 50 per cent, implying that about half the nation’s electrical energy on average is being supplied by wind. It needs to be noted, however, that the analysis does not attempt to account for the practical difficulties imposed on the standby generators needed to match supply to demand in the presence of intermittent wind power, which may become very significant at very high penetrations.

sec.title: 2 STANDBY PLANT: THE COST OF GENERAL POWER PRODUCTION
sec.p: For general plant, it is possible to ensure that the input energy (in the form of gas or coal, for instance) can be made available continuously, which means that the plant is able to run at high power for prolonged periods. While it might be possible for the plant to run at a higher power for short intervals, this would tend to violate operating constraints, such as on temperature, for example, and this would shorten the life of the plant. Hence, the term, ‘maximum continuous rating’ (MCR) is used to denote the highest, prudent power level.

For wind power, on the other hand, the input energy depends on weather conditions that are outside the operator’s control, and these constrain how long the plant will be able to run at high power, The term ‘maximum capacity’ is often used to denote the highest power at which it is prudent for a wind plant to generate. The two terms ‘MCR’ and ‘maximum capacity’ are regarded as synonymous in this article, meaning that the highest power at which a plant of any type may be run prudently.

Following the convention adopted by the Department for Energy and Climate Change (DECC) [3] to allow for intercomparability among different forms of electricity generation, the cost relations below are developed under the assumption of base-load conditions, so that the grid is prepared to buy all the electricity produced by the power plant. Effectively, this implies an optimal or near-optimal provision of generating plant, without surplus capacity beyond that needed to cope with the plant outages, planned and forced, that can be expected.

The following analysis applies to a fleet of similar, general power stations, each with an MCR of Mgi (MW), so that the aggregate MCR is Mg=∑iMgi. To a first approximation, the non-fuel costs, namely capital, depreciation, operations, maintenance, and decommissioning, may be considered proportional to the amount of installed capacity, with a constant of proportionality, kg, common to all members of the fleet. The word ‘planned’ in equation (3) signifies that the output of electrical energy will be that which can reasonably be expected, after taking into account downtime or reduced power running, whether caused by planned maintenance or random faults, with the downtime estimated for the latter based on experience of similar plant.

The average availability for the general plant, Ag, is taken to be the ratio of planned energy output to the maximum possible when operating in base-load mode. This is related to, but not identical with the load factor. The load factor, often regarded as an empirical measure, is the ratio of the output produced by a plant in a certain period and the theoretical maximum that it could have produced. Hence, the load factor takes actual grid demand into account also [4]. The availability, Ag, as just defined, covers the reliability of the generating plant and also its fuel supply, although the latter is not usually a major contributor for general plant (fossil fuelled or nuclear).

It may be noted that the term availability is sometimes used in connection with components having only two states: working or failed [5]. In such a case, it denotes the fraction of time that the component is in the working state. The definition here is a generalization of this concept in that the state is not binary in nature, but a continuous variable in the range 0 per cent to 100 per cent MCR. sec.title: 3 INTRODUCING THE DOM FOR BACK-UP GENERATION
sec.p: Wind power penetration, βw, is taken to be the ratio of the average wind power sent out to consumers’ average demand for electricity over a prolonged period, typically a year. When wind power penetration of the total electricity mix is relatively small, it is possible to assume that all the electricity generated by wind farms will be bought and consumed, including during those times when the turbines are operating at their MCR.

Clearly, the wind farms’ MCR power, Mw.max, cannot be used if it is more than the total power people want ever to consume. Hence the first and overriding requirement is (5a) where Pd.max is the maximum power demand over the whole period being considered. Furthermore, if the full wind power output is to be consumed at all times, then it must be less than the minimum that consumers want to use, so that condition (5a) can be tightened to (5b) where Pd.min is the consumers’ minimum power demand. Clearly, condition (5b) implies condition (5a), but the reason for stating the two conditions will become clear later.

While a small fraction of consumers’ power demand will show a correlation with wind speed, most demand for electricity will be independent of how strongly the wind is blowing. Thus, since the MCR of wind farms is available only transiently, continuity of power supply means that the electricity will have to be supplied from another source when the weather is calm and the wind turbines are working at less than full output.

The DOM is introduced here. It is suggested that, in return for purchasing all the wind power that they can produce at all times, wind power operators should make a declaration that they will supply an amount of power sent out equal to the MCR of their wind farms. Thus, in return for a guarantee of purchase, the grid will impose a matching obligation to cover the provision of back-up generation to make up the shortfall during those periods when the wind farms are unable to operate and supply at MCR because wind speeds are low.

The grid must find this back-up generation from somewhere if it is both to use all the energy that a wind farm can produce and also maintain continuity of supply to its clients. Without this backup, the supply of electrical energy would fall as the period of maximum wind energy came to an end when the wind ceased to blow as hard. For example, Germany’s largest wind energy supplier, E.ON Netz, reported a loss of 4 GW of wind power feed-in in the 10 h between 9.00 am and 7.00 pm on 24 December 2004, equivalent to the capacity of 8 × 500 MW coal fired power station blocks [6].

While backup is needed for all forms of generation, the requirement for standby has a greater prominence for wind power because of the highly intermittent nature of wind. The periods of low or zero output are significantly rarer for a conventional plant, which will therefore need to draw on back-up capacity with a frequency that is an order of magnitude less than that of a wind installation. Moreover, conventional plants provide a good source of back-up capacity because not only is each available to generate at its MCR for most of the time, but also plant downtimes for conventional plants result from largely uncorrelated causes. By contrast, wind plants constitute poor vehicles for backup because their violation of both these points. With regard to common-cause downtime, periods of calm weather can lead to low or zero outputs from many wind farms, all at the same time, even when they are located hundreds of miles apart.

These factors mean that it is necessary to treat with caution the claim sometimes made for the statistic, ‘capacity credit’ [7], namely that it represents the fraction of conventional generation to which wind generation is equivalent in terms of the maintenance of continuity of supply. The large qualitative and quantitative differences between conventional plant and wind installations mean that, while the statistic can have useful illustrative features [8], no consistent equivalence between the two forms of generation can be established. Nor is there, even in principle, a single definitive value for the capacity value of a given generator [9], and the values calculated will depend both on the level of wind penetration and on the characteristics of the rest of the generators supplying the grid. Hence, for example, while E.ON Netz regarded 8 per cent of its 7 GW of installed wind capacity in 2005 as ‘secure production capacity’, it considered that, should wind power rise to 48 GW installed capacity, only 4 per cent of that amount could be regarded as replacing traditional power production as far as supply security was concerned [6]. Generally, the visualization tool offered by the capacity credit has limited usefulness when very large wind penetrations are studied, as in this article. By contrast, the DOM developed here gives useful guidance on costs up to a wind penetration of 50 per cent, and, in modified form, well beyond that level.

The requirement for backup represents an unavoidable cost that needs to be recognized for wind. An equal treatment of wind energy producers and energy producers from other sources would suggest that the obligation and hence cost for the back-up supply specific to wind be placed on the wind generator. However, even if the wind energy producer is deliberately sheltered from the cost, this back-up generation will need to be paid for, whoever is chosen finally to bear that cost.

Wind power installations will be able to supply only a small fraction, Aw, of their MCR over any prolonged period, which fraction will be denoted by their availability. As with Ag, this measure encompasses both the reliability of the plant, wind turbines in this instance, and that of the supply of ‘fuel’, in this case wind. This availability is an average value, defined as (6) where mw(t) is the instantaneously available wind power output and Mw.ave the average wind power output, assumed to be accepted by the grid. Hence, the availability of wind power will be given as (7) implying (8) in which the instantaneous availability, aw(t), at time, t, is given as the ratio of the instantaneously available wind power output, mw(t), to wind MCR, Mw.max (9)

The shortfall in wind energy from wind farms of maximum capacity, Mw.max (MW), over any prolonged time period, T, will then be Mw.maxT-AwMw.maxT=(1-Aw)Mw.maxT or QwMw.maxT, where Qw=1-Aw is denoted the average unavailability of the wind installation.

Meanwhile, standby general power stations will be able to supply energy, when called upon, at an average rate of AgMgs (MW), where Mgs is the maximum capacity of standby general power production (MW) and the availability, Ag, of general power stations is analogously defined to the availability of wind power installations (10) (11) If called upon to supply power for the same prolonged period, T, the energy the standby, general power stations can be expected to supply is AgMgsT.

The basic requirement for the standby power station is that it should have the capacity to make up the shortfall of the wind farm. This will imply, inter alia, that the expected replacement energy from standby generation should be able to match the shortfall in wind energy over any prolonged period, T. This implies (12) so that the standby ratio, s, defined as the ratio of the MCR of the standby plant to that of the wind farms, must obey (13)

Since the data indicate that Qw<Ag, it follows that Qw/Ag<1. For example, the load factor of wind farms in the UK is given by Sharman [10] as in the range 25 per cent to 35 per cent. Since the grid would have taken all the wind power produced, this implies an availability, Aw, in the same range. Meanwhile, it is possible to calculate the availability of wind power for the cases given by DECC [3] by multiplying together the ‘plant availability’ and the wind-dependent ‘load factor’ in the base-load conditions assumed. For Nth of a kind wind farms, where ‘medium’ technological upgrades have occurred, this gives the availability of onshore wind generation as 0.274 and offshore as 0.393, with an average of 0.334. In this analysis, the average availability of wind farms will be taken to be Aw=0.35. Hence, Qw=0.65. The use of a single, average value of availability across both onshore and offshore wind farms means that the relations derived are valid when applied to the total power produced by all the wind farms in the UK. They will be approximately valid when applied to the power produced by a single wind farm, to the extent that wind farm may be regarded as typical.

The plant availability of first of a kind combined cycle gas turbine (CCGT) plant and coal plant is given by DECC [3] as between 87 per cent and 91 per cent. Under DECC’s standard costing assumption of base-load generation, this implies an availability for general plant, Ag, of the same range. Allowing for a small degree of conservatism, this study takes the availability of general power production to be 85 per cent, Ag=0.85. Hence, the first condition on standby ratio is s ≥ 0.765.

If, however, the lower limit were used to set the standby ratio at this value, s = 0.765, then the combination of wind power and standby power could maintain a combined power output equivalent to the wind power MCR, Mw.max, only if the wind power component was greater than (1-0.765)Mw.max=0.235Mw.max at all times. In fact, wind power in the UK will be below this level for about 40 per cent of the time [11], so that this standby ratio is too low to give any reasonable assurance of continuity of supply.

In fact, wind turbines, geographically dispersed in the UK, are likely to produce less than about 4 per cent of their MCR for 20 per cent of the time [11]. Hence, a more stringent condition is necessary if standby generation to have a reasonable chance of replacing the whole of the wind power output when it is becalmed, namely (14) or (15) with the general power availability taken to be 85 per cent, as quoted above, the standby ratio becomes s ≥ 1.176.

For the case of widespread becalming, the grid becomes reliant on the output from general power stations only. Equation (14) represents the condition that the standby general power plant will, on average, be able to take over the full capacity, Mw.max, of the wind installations, as it would need to in this situation. The capacity condition on the standby power plant is thus Mgs≥Mw.max/Ag, and in the limiting condition of equality, the nominal excess capacity of the general plant over the load it needs to supply is Mgs-Mw.max=Mw.max/Ag-Mw.max. The fractional excess, which may be denoted as the capacity margin, is then (Mgs-Mw.max)/Mw.max=1/Ag-1=slow-1. Thus, when s=slow=1.176, the capacity margin is 17.6 per cent.

A capacity margin of 17.6 per cent would result in a low frequency of interruption, although the ultimately stochastic nature of supply as well as demand means that this will not offer a complete guarantee of uninterrupted supply.

The figure of 17.6 per cent may be compared with the UK capacity margin of 16.5 per cent that existed in the winter of 2003–2004, a figure regarded as inadequate, being too far below the target of 20 per cent for the UK’s electricity system suggested by the Parliamentary Office of Science and Technology [12]. As a further comparison, the Central Electricity Generation Board operated to a capacity margin of 28 per cent in the early 1980s. Generally, one may regard (16) as a reasonable minimum level for the standby ratio.

sec.title: 4 COST OF STANDBY GENERATION UNDER THE DOM

The standby general power stations will be called upon to supply the shortfall of electrical energy from the wind power farms, which, over a prolonged period, T, has been derived above as QwMw.maxT. While the standby power stations will receive income for the energy supplied, this energy will constitute only a fraction of their total production capacity over the same period, which will be AgMgsT=AgsMw.maxT=Mw.maxT. Therefore, the fraction, g, of the potential output from the standby general stations that will produce income is (18)

Conversely, the fraction, f, of the standby generators’ potential output that earns no income, the idle fraction, will be (19) It is only this fraction, f, of output and income forgone that needs to be paid for, by the wind farms under the DOM.

Under the DOM, the wind farms will pick up the costs associated with the production shortfall of the standby generators. By its nature, this production shortfall will incur no fuel costs, and the concern will be with the total non-fuel cost of the standby capacity, Mgs, which will be given by (20) where equations (1), (15), and (16) have been used to derive the final result. Thus, the cost of the standby capacity attributable to the wind farms is (21)

Given a cost per unit of capital, rc, the annual outgoing needed to service the standby capacity attributable to the wind farms will be (22) The levelized cost of wind energy, (£/MWh) caused by the need to maintain standby capacity will be found by dividing the non-fuel cost per year, rcCgsw, by the amount of wind-generated energy, 8766AwMw.max (MWh/year) (23)

Comparing equations (4) and (23), it is clear that the levelized cost of standby generation in £/MWh attributable to wind will be the same as the specific non-fuel cost for general power production (24) Hence, substituting into equation (17), the total levelized cost of wind energy (£/MWh) will be (25) The average amount of wind energy supplied over a long period, T, is AwMw.maxT, equivalent to wind farms of aggregate average power, AwMw.max, continuously producing electricity over the period. The total cost (£) of the energy sent out in the period will be (26) Hence, the standby cost for wind is equivalent to that of building, staffing, and maintaining general power stations continuously sending out power at an average rate of AwMw.max (MW). This implies a need for standby general power stations of aggregate MCR, Mgs=AwMw.max/Ag(MW).

This is a striking result. Under the DOM, wind power needs to bear the cost not only of building and maintaining the wind turbines, but also building, staffing, maintaining, and decommissioning a general power station sending out the same average power. Thus, wind farms with a total of 1000 turbines of 1 MW MCR would expect to send out 350 MW and would need back-up generation of 1000/Ag≈1175 MW MCR. Thus, they would need to bear a fraction of the back-up costs equivalent to building, staffing, and maintaining a general power station with an MCR of 350/Ag≈410 MW.

It should be noted that the DOM does not attempt to account for the practical difficulties likely to be associated with the load scheduling and load following needed to match supply to demand in the presence of intermittent wind power. It is accepted that additional costs might arise from the need to maintain spinning reserve, the loss of station efficiency from operating off-design, at part load, and possible extra maintenance resulting from the accelerated ageing of components as a result of high levels of temperature cycling. Hence, while the DOM gives a reasonable indication of the scale of the costs involved with providing the necessary standby capacity, it will tend to underestimate somewhat the additional charge that wind power is obliged to bear if it is to pick up its full share of maintaining continuity of supply at all times.

sec.title: 5 THE UPPER LIMIT OF WIND PENETRATION OF THE ENERGY FOR WHICH THE DOM IS APPLICABLE
sec.p: Potential wind penetration, Bw, will be defined as the ratio of the average amount, Mw.aveT, of electrical energy that can be supplied by wind over a long period, T, to the total amount of electrical energy consumed over the same period (27) where Pd.ave is the average power demand. Meanwhile, actual wind penetration, βw, is defined as the ratio of the average amount, Mw.ave|dT, of electrical energy that is actually supplied, in the presence of demand, by wind over a long period, T, to the total amount of electrical energy consumed (28)

It may be observed, in general, that the actual penetration cannot exceed the potential: βw≤Bw, but if those running the grid are instructed to take wind power whenever they can, then βw≈Bw when Bw is low.

The average power demand, Pd.ave, is approximately 40 GW in the UK [13], while the maximum power demand, Pd.max, is about 60 GW [13, 14]. The minimum power demand, Pd.min, is about 20 GW [10], so that consumers’ demand for electric power is roughly symmetrical about the mean.

sec.title: 6 NUMERICAL CALCULATION OF THE UPPER BOUNDARY FOR THE DOM
sec.p: Probability distributions for both wind power and power demand are needed to carry out the numerical calculations. By the central limit theorem, the sum of a large number of independent, identically distributed random variables will obey a normal distribution. The requirement for identical distributions may be relaxed formally according to the Lindeberg condition [15] and, moreover, the deviation from the normal distribution can be small even when the Lindeberg condition is not satisfied fully [16]. It is reasonable to suppose that the probability distributions for power from different wind farms will be sufficiently similar that the normality result is not compromised too strongly. Furthermore, the central limit theorem remains true for sufficiently weakly correlated variables [16], and a formal proof for the situation where blocks of random variables within the sum are dependent is given in Hoeffding and Robbins [17]. This latter provides a reasonable model for the outputs of wind farms that are geographically dispersed across the UK. The power outputs from those wind farms that are located close together will be more highly correlated, while the correlation for those that are geographically distant will exhibit only a small degree of correlation. Overall, it is reasonable to assume that the sum of the outputs of a very large number of wind farms will be subject to a probability distribution that will be approximately normal.

It is suggested in PelaFlow Consulting [11] that the standard deviation for a large collection of wind farms will lie between a quarter and a half of the mean. Accordingly, this study’s central calculations will be carried out with the standard deviation for wind power set at the arithmetic average of these two figures, namely three-eighths of the mean.

Turning to power demand, similar arguments using the central limit theorem will come into play as for wind, since national power demand will be made up of many individual decisions on power use, even accepting that a proportion of these decisions will be correlated. Hence, as suggested in Pedersen and Ulseth [18], the power demand should be roughly normal, a proposition fully in agreement with the symmetrical upper and lower limits observed (see equations (30) and (31) above). Thus, it will be assumed in this article that the distribution for power demand will be normal but truncated at the upper and lower limits ±Ndσd, where σd is the standard deviation for power demand. This entails compensating the normal probability density by dividing by the difference, Φ(Nd)-Φ(-Nd), where Φ(.) is the standard normal cumulative probability. Meanwhile, the standard deviation for power demand, σd, is given as (39) where the second step follows from equation (30). Nd was used as an input variable, set to 3 for the central calculations, but could be varied in sensitivity studies to give significantly different probability distributions when Nd=1, 1.5, 2, etc.

Since current UK practice is for wind power to be taken in preference to other sources, provided that there is sufficient overall demand to accommodate it, the power output of wind will be constrained to be no more than the demand for power. Hence, for any pair of values (Mw,Pd), the actual power sent out will be min(Mw,Pd). All the wind power produced can be consumed provided there is at least that level of demand: Pd≥Mw. The limiting case of Pd=Mw has been plotted; this line of unit slope may be termed the ‘iso-power’ line. Provided the probability density ‘target’ lies above the iso-power line, demand will impose no constraint and the full wind power produced will be sent out and consumed. The demand will impose a constraint only when it lies below the iso-power line. It will be seen from the graph that very little of the target falls below this line when the potential wind penetration is Bw=0.525 (which is essentially the same as actual wind penetration, βw, at this point, Fig. 3). Thus, the probability of a combination of high wind power and low demand is low. Moreover, the portion of the target that falls below the iso-power line will still lie above the line of slope, 0.8, as shown. Therefore, the contribution that this area of the target makes to the average power will be at least 80 per cent of what it would have been if there had been no demand constraint. Since the portion of the target below the iso-power line is in any case small, it is easy to understand that, while the average power taken by the grid will start falling once Bw>Aw/h(2h-1), the fall-off will be gradual. sec.title: 11 DISCUSSION
sec.p: At low wind penetrations, it is possible for the grid to take all the power that the nation’s wind farms can produce, right up to their combined MCR, provided the other forms of generation are prepared to make the necessary cuts in their output to cope with its intermittency. Strictly, the limiting condition occurs when wind power’s combined MCR reaches the minimum demand for power, which happens at a wind power penetration of about 17.5 per cent. However, the scope for the other types of generators to reduce their production to compensate for occasional high levels of wind power means that a much firmer limit occurs near the point where wind power’s MCR reaches the maximum demand for power. It has been demonstrated using estimated probability distributions that almost all wind power’s production can still be accepted by the grid up to close to this upper limit, where wind power’s penetration is about 50 per cent. This degree of wind penetration is higher than the levels at which most discourse on the subject has centred so far, although the Committee on Climate Change has recently suggested a penetration of 45 per cent for all renewable energy would be technically feasible by 2030 [1], with between 60 per cent and 80 per cent possible by 2050. Furthermore, the surplus of wind power that needs to be rejected rises relatively slowly beyond the 50 per cent point, suggesting that the theoretical limits to wind power are rather wide. However, the analysis does not attempt to account for the practical difficulties imposed on the standby generators needed to match supply to demand in the presence of intermittent wind power.

This article introduces the DOM, under which, in return for guaranteeing to purchase all the power a wind farm can produce up to its declared MCR, the electricity grid imposes a matching obligation on wind generators to provide back-up plant to make up the shortfall during times when the wind farm is unable to operate at its full rating because wind speed is low. However, the standby cost that wind power needs to bear is significantly reduced because the DOM takes benefit from the ability of the standby generators to sell their electricity in the market when called upon. For wind penetrations of less than about 50 per cent, the percentage of the standby costs that is offset is equal to the unavailability of wind power, Qw, thus about 65 per cent. The required amount of standby generation reaches saturation when the aggregate standby power can satisfy the nation’s maximum demand, after allowing for its availability. However, although the standby capacity stays constant for penetrations in excess of about 50 per cent, its idle fraction increases in proportion to the penetration. Thus, the general result is found, applicable at all wind penetrations, that the levelized cost of wind energy needs to include the levelized, non-fuel costs of general power stations of the same power sent out in addition to the cost of constructing and maintaining its wind turbines.

Evaluating the figures for onshore and offshore wind power used in Thomas and Chrysanthou [19], the DOM suggests that for today’s conditions the extra requirement on wind power is a relatively modest fraction of its levelized cost without standby, between 11.9 per cent for offshore wind and 16 per cent for onshore. These standby premia are significantly lower than the figures implied by the PB Power study described in Parliamentary Office of Science and Technology [2], namely 31 per cent and 46 per cent, respectively. Interestingly, these RAEng 2004 figures can be reproduced approximately if no benefit is taken from the standby plant selling their electricity into the market when wind power is unable to meet its full obligation. It is easiest to work out the corresponding figures for cases where the wind penetration is less than 50 per cent.

While under the DOM the fraction of standby output and income forgone that needs to be paid for by wind power, f, is taken to be the availability of wind, f=Aw (equation (19)), if it is assumed that wind power has to bear the full cost, so that f = 1, then the corresponding percentages become 11.9/Aw=11.9/0.35=34 per cent and 16/Aw=16/0.35=45.7 per cent.

sec.title: 12 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The wind power penetration at which the grid can accept all the wind energy produced will be conditioned by the fundamental limit that wind power’s aggregate MCR cannot be greater than the nation’s minimum power demand. However, it has been shown that this penetration, about 17.5 per cent using current UK figures, does not constitute a hard limit. Based on general considerations and a relatively small amount of easily available data, it can be shown that almost all wind power can be accepted up to the point where wind power’s aggregate MCR is equal to the maximum power demand. This occurs at a wind power penetration of about 50 per cent, a larger fraction than has been acknowledged generally hitherto. Furthermore, the surplus of wind power that needs to be rejected rises relatively slowly beyond this point, and so it is clear that the theoretical limits to wind power are rather wide. However, the analysis has not attempted to account for the practical difficulties imposed on the standby generators needed to match supply to demand in the presence of intermittent wind power.

The intermittency of wind power means that high levels of back-up generation will be needed as standby. For low-to-medium wind penetrations, the DOM obliges wind power to provide standby generation equal to wind power’s combined MCR plus a capacity factor to allow for the unavailability of general power production. However, the required standby generation reaches a point of saturation when wind power is supplying about 50 per cent of the nation’s electricity. At this point, the back-up generation has the capacity to supply the nation’s peak demand for power, so that providing further standby capacity would be pointless.

The fact that the DOM allows for the standby generators to sell their electricity in the market when called upon to do so means that the standby charge on wind power is significantly reduced. At all wind penetrations, the levelized cost of wind energy needs to include the levelized, non-fuel costs of general power stations of the same power sent out in addition to the cost of constructing and maintaining its wind turbines.

The implications for the cost of wind power are best understood using the concept of a standby premium, the fractional additional cost of wind energy needed to cover the appropriate level of standby capacity. For today’s conditions, the extra requirement on wind power is, in fact, a relatively modest fraction of its levelized cost without standby, between 12 per cent of for offshore wind and 16 per cent for onshore. These percentages are roughly a third of those presented in 2004 by the Royal Academy of Engineering.

Wind power will become competitive with general power production when the fuel cost per MWh associated with general generation has risen to match the levelized cost of constructing and operating the wind turbines without standby. Once this point has been reached, the general power producer will regard wind power as a good, fuel-saving investment. This prompts the notion of wind power as an adjunct to general power production rather than as a wholly independent source of energy.

The DOM outlines a set of basic principles for securing sufficient, reliable capacity to ensure continuity of supply when a portion, possibly a very large portion, of electricity generation is intermittent. As such, it provides a contribution to the debate on a market-wide capacity mechanism that needs to be developed, as discussed in the 2011 White Paper on electricity market reform [20].
